clinical_study.official_title: Analgesic Control Following Knee Arthroscopy: Results of a Randomised , Double-blinded Trial Comparing a Hyaluronic Acid Supplement to Bupivacaine

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to investigate the analgesic effects offered by bupivacaine and Durolane (a hyaluronic acid supplement) administered immediately following the completion of knee arthroscopy.

detailed_description.textblock: There is increasing evidence of the toxic effects of intraarticular administration of local anaesthetic. Hyaluronic acid supplementation given at the time of knee arthroscopy has not been fully evaluated as a possible alternative. We have studied the efficacy of a hyaluronic acid (HA) supplement (Durolane®) and a local anaesthetic (Bupivacaine) at providing early and short-term post-operative analgesic control following knee arthroscopy.Patients will be randomised to receive either 10mls of 0.5% Bupivacaine or 10mls of Durolane® into the joint immediately after completion of surgery. WOMAC and Tegner-Lysholm scores were obtained at baseline then at 1, 2, and 6-weeks post surgery. VAS pain scores were obtained at baseline; 1 and 24-hours; and 1, 2 and 6 weeks following surgery.
